title.value: Последействие пожнивных посевов безэруковых и низкоглюкозинолатных сортов капустных культур на урожайность зерновой культуры
Aftereffect of post harvest sowing of low erucic and low glucosinolate varieties of cabbage crops on cereal crop yield

journal.title: Arable Farming and Breeding in Belarus : collection of scientific papers

person.name: Dolgova, E.L., National Academy of Sciences (Belarus). Scientific and Practical Center for  Arable Farming

abstract.value: A brief analysis of the literature on the importance of post harvest sowing in crop rotations and its aftereffect on yield of subsequent crops was presented in the conditions of the Republic of Belarus. According to studies conducted in 2011-2012, the increase of biological activity of the soil in spring wheat (Triticum aestivum) placed after post harvest crops was registered. Besides, the biological activity increased with increasing of doses of nitrogen fertilizers applied under post harvest crops. For two years, the average wheat yield increased from 38.8 q/ha on control plot (average for four crops) to 41.6 q/ha at N120 or by 7.2%. Crop plantings of non-erucic varieties of cabbage crop (Cruciferae) during the growing season accumulated organic matter due to post-harvest residues (postcut crop + root) at a dose of 120 kg of nitrogen / ha to 25.4 t/ha of dry matter (winter rape (Brassica napus)). Postharvest crop of spring oilseed rape and winter rape showed insignificantly lower indexes. The accumulation of organic residues increased with increasing crop yields due to increasing doses of nitrogen. Oilseed radish according to the accumulation indexes of organic residues (33.4 t/ha at N120) was superior over other studied crops. Increasing doses of nitrogen for crop culture up to 120 kg/ha along with an increase in their productivity increased the yield of spring wheat in the 5.4-11.7%.
